ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Developed skills to help critically think about physiology problems more.
Knowledge of different psychological systems like metabolism, energetics, etc. mostly at the cellular level.
Fairly technical overview of vertebrate physiology, from the genetic, epigenetic, cellular and sometimes ecological perspectives.
I learned about aspects of animal and comparative physiology, as well as relevant research methods and how the field has evolved over time.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: interpretive dances and crocodile walking, Prof. Moyer is a genuinely nice guy and the only other thing I'll say about him is that he grows on you

Weaknesses: exams are kind of hard and require you think apply your knowledge to a new scenario, they are also pretty long
The prepared slides were good to study off of, and the tests would not really give any suprises.
The material is interesting and the assignments are straightforward, but the exams are difficult to study for due to the nature of the questions.

The breakdown of assignments between exams, written p-sets and the presentation at the end of the course was helpful  the variety makes it easier to learn things. But I wish the grading had been slightly more evenly distributed (perhaps one more p-set, to balance out the exams?), and that the lectures had been slightly more interactive, given that it wasn't an especially big class (less than 20 students  a few more "turn-and-talk" discussions, or even a doodle poll every once in a while would have been helpful I think).
I thought this course was great, definitely one of the best science classes I've taken at Yale. Wouldn't change anything about it.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Not really, unless you are an E&EB major
This is a great course to have under your belt no matter what your year and major is.
I would if they have an interest in physiology, but with the caveat that the exams are quite difficult.

Yes! It was so interesting learning about how the body functions both in humans and in other organisms. There are so many really cool topics taught in the class that will really make you think about how complex and interesting physiology is. It is also really interesting learning about how physiology is impacted by environment, as there are so many methods of adaptation that I never knew existed. If you are pre med, I would highly recommend this class as it puts into perspective classes like biochem and physics and shows you why they matter in a medical sense.
Definitely would recommend this course! Professor Moyer is a great lecturer, and the course is very well-organized. Clear guidelines are laid out for each assignment, which I found very helpful.
